awd_titl_txt: NSF 2026: EAGER: Accelerated carbon mineralization sequestration in cation rich rock formations via microbial augmentation and stimulation
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental and Transport Systems and the NSF 2026 Program in the Office of Integrated Activities, Professors Lingwall, Sani, and Ustunisik and their team at South Dakota School of Mines and Technology explore biologically accelerated carbon mineralization processes in cation rich rock formations.  One approach for mitigating excessive carbon dioxide (CO2) in the atmosphere, a factor that contributes to extreme weather and wildfires, is to reduce excessive CO2 levels by capture and storage. However, storage runs the risk that CO2 injected underground as a fluid can migrate and escape. Fortunately, nature has provided a solution through carbonate mineralization in deep rock, which has recently been shown to sequester large quantities of CO2. This award develops laboratory data that would be needed for the design of a potentially high-capacity, long-term carbon sequestration system. As opposed to other processes that rely on fluid CO2 to stay contained below a caprock, this system stores the carbon in the rock as part of the rock itself. A future benefit of such a system is that, as opposed to fracking which induces seismicity, this can be used to reduce seismicity through binding of deep faults. Another potential impact of such technology, if deployed at scale, would be to contribute to sustainability and resilience by reducing extreme weather and wildfire risks.  The educational goal of the project is to create interest and curiosity among a diverse range of students by developing demonstrations on greenhouse gas biomineralization.   

The team’s recent work in biomineralization and the evaluation of recent demonstrations shows that biology accelerates carbon mineralization in basalts. Moreover, natural and injected recovery brines at depth contain high concentrations of calcium and magnesium, providing additional cation sources. Thus, the team has the opportunity to identify natural processes for sequestration via carbonate mineralization from either bioaugmentation or biostimulation in deep rock. This award is to perform laboratory experiments using extremophiles from the database of biomineralizing microbes to observe and measure this phenomenon. The goal of this project is to produce unique data on microbially accelerated carbon sequestration through laboratory core scale bioaugmentation and biostimulation experiments at appropriate temperatures and pressures. In this research, various extremophiles known to initiate biomineralization will be tested for the conversion of liquid CO2 into calcite polymorphs in deep basalt environments. This project has four principle components: 1) select and characterize rock to be optimal candidates; 2) select biomineralizing extremophiles that can tolerate the pH induced by CO2 injection; 3) study the mineralization of these rocks with CO2 without microbes; and 4) study the biomineralization of these microbes through biostimulation or bioaugmentation. This work is transdisciplinary in nature and is a convergence of expertise from geologic sciences, engineering, and microbiology to use different instruments and methods across conventional disciplinary boundaries. 

This project further explores the concepts emerged from several NSF 2026 Idea Machine winning topics: Bioinspired energy utilization; Engineered living materials; Geomimicry; Global microbiome in a changing world; Public carbon capture and sequestration; and Terraforming earth.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award into accelerated carbon mineralization sequestration in cation rich rock formations via microbial augmentation and stimulation has reached its intended outcomes. When this award was proposed, the vision for use of polyextremophilic microbes for carbon sequestration through mineralization in vastly accelerated timescales in a variety of deep geologic formations was high-risk, high-reward. As the award concludes, the products of this research demonstrate that the concept is valid. The products of this research show scalability and replicability. The products of this research are enabling commercialization and economic development for the State of South Dakota. New knowledge in the enzyme production of polyextremophiles has been generated. New microbes from the deep subsurface have been sampled. Proprietary new microbes have been developed using synthetic biology tools.

In terms of polyextremophile identification, rock and groundwater were sampled from deep in the Sanford Underground Mine in Lead, SD. At depths of approximately one mile below ground surface, rock and groundwater were carefully sampled to prevent microbe contamination, and then transported under ice to the laboratory. Carefully grinding the rock to access yet preserve the DNA, DNA samples from rock and water were taken and processed. Using genomics and transcriptomics tools, the varieties of bacteria living under the multiple extreme conditions were revealed. The environmental conditions at the depths needed for carbon sequestration have extreme pH, temperature, pressure, salinity and low nutrient availability requiring polyextremophiles.

In terms of work in the area of synthetic biology and polyextremophile enzyme activity, a particular strain of bacteria identified in the deep rock, but isolated fully from a local agricultural site where the bacteria was also growing in a more nutrient rich environment, was studied and then engineered. This microbe is a polyextremophile and has capacity for elevated carbonic anhydrase and urease activity. Evaluation of urease activity was found to be adequate for ureolytic biomineralization. However, the work of this award required a low nitrogen and high carbon dioxide biomineralization pathway. Using synthetic biology tools, the microbe was engineered for other biomineralizing enzyme genes. Thus this microbe can survive the environment needed for carbon sequestration while also producing the enzymes needed to accelerate the process.

In terms of demonstrated carbon mineralization as accelerated by microbial activity in the temperatures, pressures, salinity and other environmental conditions of deep rock (deeper than 500-m below ground surface needed for carbon sequestration), a custom experimental chamber was designed and fabricated to provide the temperature, pressure and other environmental conditions relevant to sequestration. Using seed minerals (ultra mafic, basalts, etc.) experiments showed minor carbonate mineralization in two-week periods. However, when the specific engineered microbe was introduced, calcite production occurred rapidly and at scale within two-weeks. This was replicated several times and careful measurements made to document the calcite precipitation and mineralizing of carbon into rock.

The resources and research of this award enabled significant achievements in Broader Impacts. Firstly, the products of this research enabled for the development and implementation of a workshop on bio-inspired engineering for the annual Black Hills Women in Science two-day event. Over the period of the award, an estimated 2,400 7th and 8th grade girls were hosted at the workshop for part of their day. Second, the bio-inspired engineering workshop was modified and presented to incoming freshmen engineering students as part of their welcome-to-campus orientation. An estimated 480 incoming freshmen across all engineering disciplines were thus exposed to new ways of seeing engineering through the bio-inspired and bio-mimetic lens. Multiple undergraduate research assistants were able to synergize cutting-edge research with concurrent theoretical lectures in their coursework on microbiology and geology. Lastly, the investigators of this award were able to work with researchers outside the typical collaborations of civil and chemical engineering, biology, microbiology, geology and petrology, and increase their research networks. The products of this award translate beyond civil engineering and impact biology and ecology. By development of an experimentally based and theoretically valid understanding of polyextremophiles, this work will enable researchers from these fields to better understand the organisms and the organismal role in the ecosystem as well as performance and longevity of these microbes in the face of extreme climactic conditions and natural disasters.
